Entry.1:
Dear Nell,

I enlisted today and I have bought this book to make a diary, during the time I am away at the front.

I hope to get away soon for I am going into camp straight away, so I intend to start it off the day I sail, so that, from that day on you will have an account of what I did in the Great War.

Your loving Brother

Harry
Entry.2:
I have been waiting five months or thereabouts for the day that I would open up this diary; but today I make a start.

My company, the
Entry.4: Battalion left Liverpool Camp at 2 P.M. From the Central Station, we march in procession through the streets to the Domain. There were great crowds in the streets and the fellows made a good show. We were reviewed in the "Domain" by the Governor and Major General McCay. Then we marched out to the Agricultural Ground where we are to camp the night as we will not embark till tomorrow morning. General leave has been granted till10 P.M.
Entry.5: We left the Agricultural Ground early. Special trams conveyed us to Circular Quay. My company was embarked by 7.30 A.M. No one was missing, but we were one man too many, he was put off. It was hard on him after training in the company for five months. The ship is the Orient Liner, "Osterly"; we are lucky to get such a fine boat. All the troops were embarked by 10 A.M. then the people were allowed on the wharf. As the ship drew away from the Quay we broke hundreds of ribbons with the people ashore, and there was much cheering, all the chaps were in great spirits. The ship anchored in the stream till she got her clearance; and there was much crowing by the ferry boat whistles. We cleared the Heads so after 1 P.M. We are away!
Entry.6:
A quiet Sunday and we are shaking down into our new home. Am comfortable enough, I’m with a lot of fine chaps. My company has for officers.Leiut Taylor.O.C.,Leiut Lacy, Lenahan, & Prescott, rather decent fellows. Our quarters are on the lower deck. The mess tables occupy both sides of the deck, in the middle are the hammock racks. We sleep in hammocks suspended from the beams above. There are 16 at my mess table, it is numbered, and our rations are portioned and served to mess orderlies at the "galley" amidships. 

As the "Osterly" is carrying passengers we are rather cramped for deck space, for the promenade decks are reserved for them. The sea is quite calm.
Entry.7: Arrived at Port Melbourne at 8 A.M. Some one releived me of most of my money. Have heard this is a common nuisance on troop ships. General leave granted. I went out to North Melbourne to see Holdsworth. Found him at home and we had a jolly day of it; you bet I enjoyed being in my home town. There was some disturbance in the city; as I was returning to the ship about midnight I got into a rather a boisterious crowd. I don’t know what it was all about but some misguided burst of patriotic enthusisiam I believe. Anyway a couple of the fellows at my table received cracks over the head from policemen’s batons. I returned to the ship alright.
Entry.8: There was no leave today. Because some of the fellows were detained by the police in the city last night. I reckon that the "John Hops" made a mark of our fellows because they were conspicuous with N.S.W. pencilled on their hat bands. The Governor of Victoria, Sir. A. Stanley came onto the ship and delivered an address. The usual rot about, "heroes going to fight." But they stop their leave because they get drunk. Holdsworth came down onto the pier and I was allowed to get off the ship to speak to him, and tell him good-bye. There was quite a crowd on the pier to tell us good –bye when the ship left the pier at 6 P.M. and anchored in the channels. We are not likely to get into mischief here.
Entry.9: The "Osterly" sailed at 3.30 P.M. We passed Queenscliff and Pt Lonsdale about sunset and I was able to get a good look at the old beach were we used to play when we were kiddies. I saw our old home quite plainly, the sight of that little old house where I was born woke a lot of memoires. We dropped the pilot onside the "Rip" just as the sun went down, rather a thrilling spectacle for there was rather a heavy swell on.
Entry.10: Mal-de-Mer has claimed many victims today. There is a heavy sea running. I have had no indication of sickness as yet but I am thoroughly enjoying this trip.
Entry.11: Got to Port Adelaide at 6 A.M. A splendid wharf here. We were allowed ashore to play cricket and football. I walked a couple miles to the city and had a look around. Managed to get a ride back to the ship at Port Adelaide on a goods train. Adelaide strikes me as a pretty little city, must get a better look at it some day. The ship sailed at 5 P.M.
Entry.12: Good weather and a smooth sea; so we had fire drill today. Everyman was allotted his position in the boats and detailed to his fire station. Then a blast on the steam siren and a furious ringing of the ship’s bell was the signal to get a life belt and get into position.
Entry.13: There was a church parade this morning. The service for Australian soldiers on Active Service is beautiful. The "bight" is unusually calm passed a steamer sailing parallel to our course.
Entry.14:
Raised the land again at 9 A.M. this morning, a view of bare, forebidding cliffs and blue hills in the distance. Was detailed for guard duty today; I have to stand at the forward companion ladder and keep the common troops off the promenade deck. Was on post when we rounded Cape Leewin, at 9 P.M. The sea was very rough there, and the ship was rolling a treat. There is a splendid light on the Cape; its flash must have been visible, 40 miles.

 

Arrive in Fremantle at 6 A.M. General leave till 3 P.M. I had a look round Fremantle; a music shop was afire, and about 50 of the boys, rushed in and rescued all the stock. Musicians came forward to play the instruments as they lay in the street; so we had a concert for half and hour till the place was extinguished by the fire brigade I slipped on board a train and rode up to Perth. Just had a look round, then returned to the ship. She sailed at 5 P.M. and by sun set we had seen the last of Australia; quite a crowd watched her sink down below the horizon. Nicholson’s the music people, presented my company with a "Zonophone" and records and it is alright. It was a piece of salvage from their shop.
Entry.15: The Indian ocean must be some place if we are to plough thro’ it for the next 9 days before we get anywhere. Was paid 10/- today. The comforts fund bought us cigarettes, tobacco & chocolate. Calm sea.
Entry.16: We are well settled aboard here now. Have half an hour’s physical jerks before breakfast. Then about five hours light drill signalling, etc. during the day. The sea keeps wonderfully smooth, just like a pond.
Entry.17: There are preparations for a sports carnival. Each company will enter a team for the different events. A boxing tournament was conducted this evening. The ring being the hatch on the "after"well deck. The boxing was a very fair display.
Entry.18:
I’m mess orderly today; I have to report to the "galley" four times during the day to draw the tucker for the chaps at my mess table. There is plenty of food on this ship and it is good. For example; todays menu – Breakfast. Porridge (know to troops as "burgoo") Fried Meat Balls and Potatoes. 
Dinner
 Soup. Roast Mutton & 3 kinds of vegetables. Stewed Fruit & rice. 
Tea
 Bread,Butter & Jam. Supper 9 P.M. Biscuits and Cocoa. Cheese. The orderlies are responsible for the cleanliness of the troop deck. As there is oceans of hot water everything is thoroughly scrubbed. General inspection by the Commander of the ship every morning at 11 A.M. It is very sultry down between decks tonight many of the fellows are going to sleep on the main deck. I am right along side a porthole and can get a breeze if I leave it open.
Entry.19: Another sultry day, the sea is oily calm and the ship is making good time. We cannot be far from the "line" now. Met Viv Haswell today had a long yarn with him.
Entry.20: I was picked for guard again today but managed to get out of it. Never did a tap all day. Saw a real tropical shower this afternoon, the scuppers ran with water. There was another issue of Cigarettes, etc
Entry.21: The company tried to do bayonet fighting, but 9/10ths of ‘em were over with sea sickness or laziness, all the afternoon. A great concert was held by the passengers. The show was a good one, for there were one or two professional performers.
Entry.22: I watched the sun rise over the Island of Ceylon. A gorgeous sight. The ship entered the Colombo breakwater at 6 A.M. We got aboard lighters & were towed to the landing stage. I went round the town in Ricksa, a sort of light cart drawn by a large buck nigger. I visited the barracks, and saw the principal buildings; it strikes me as an interesting place; would like to spend a week here. I saw a very fine regiment of Indian troops in the Barracks; the
Entry.23: Punjabis. Palmer and I ate a great many strange fruits, for fruit is ridiculously cheap. The niggers are a great nuisance, there ar swarms of them, and if you don’t watch them they will charge exorbitant prices. We got back to the ship, she had finished coaling; and sailed at 10 P.M.
Entry.24: Far out at sea on a glorious day. We passed an Orient Liner today, she was a splendid spectacle, as she swept past not 300 yards away. The boxing tournament was continued this evening we are being treated to some fine sport.
Entry.25: Leiut Lenaham tipped that we would go to France; and tried to teach us some french phrases. He deserves decorating. The final of the boxing contest was fought and we had a concert in the evening.
Entry.26: Guard work again. Passed clusters of islands this morning; came abreast of Cape Guardalfure (Africa) in the afternoon. Somalie Land is a dreary looking hole. All sand dunes and thorn bushes.
Entry.27: We are getting into a busy track now; 13 steamers passed outwards today. We were past Aden at 5 P.M. and are well into the Red Sea this evening. Aden is a bare sunsmitten place to look at.
Entry.28: A chap died today, and they buried him this evening with military honours I saw a locust fall on the deck today and there was absolutely no land in sight.
Entry.29: Pay Day! We passed a french mail steamer today. She was in sight at daylight but it took us all day to catch her. The Stewards gave a good concert; and the Colonel gave out the prizes won in the sports competition. The ship’s captain, a very decent old chap span a yarn or two also.
Entry.30: The sea is wonderfully calm today, not a ripple, a perfect day too and we are in the dreadful Red Sea? We are warned for disembarkation tomorrow so there is much bustle and movement.
Entry.31: In the outer harbour at Suez at daylight. Draw alongside the quay and disembark at 4 P.M. Boarded the train that is to take us to Cario. The train is a "keystone" affair with its little engine and nigger box carriages. They are something like that Missisippi steam boat; when they blow the whistle, she stops! We are travelling very slowly over the desert There are interesting sights everywhere There are a great many niggers about riding donkeys and working in the gardens. Troops seem to be everywhere we passed one enormous camp.
Entry.32: Detrained at Zeitoum and marched to Aerodrome Camp; Heliopolos..arriving there at daylight. We go into billets in big sheds made of wicker mats, they are very cool but hardly waterproof. The tucker is all wrong we have received none today, through some regulation that will not grant us any till we have been here 24 hours. Fortunately we are able to get plenty in the town nearby. We were attached to the strength of the First Training Battalion; and the Colonel inspected us. Went right down town this evening and had a good spread at a restaurant had a look round with some more of the fellows. I think I shall enjoy living here for a while. Met a couple of chaps I know already.
Entry.33: They get at it early here, only 15 minutes between Revielle and "Fall In". This means go for your life! There was an inspection by some Major General, didn’t catch his name. Hilton Scott, Seagrott, and I went down to Heliopolis this evening.
Entry.34: Drew rifle for training purposes and went out and did some stunts on the desert. Went down town again in the evening. Saw the "Palace Hotel"; now an Australian Hospital. It is a very beautiful building.
Entry.35:
Managed to get leave to go to Cario this afternoon. Found the Anglo Egyptian Bank after some trouble, it is curious looking for any place in a foreign city. I met an obliging Egyptian 

gentleman who showed me the way to it. He was a garrulous bird very courteous in his manner but I had to be guarded with him for this place teems with spies.
Entry.36: The Battalion is for a new stunt tonight, having to lie in camp during the next three nights, resting on our arms so to speak. Each man has 100 rounds of ball ammunition, and orders to be ready to march off at a moments notice. An old precaution against a "rising" I believe. I hope something happens to make it worth while for there will be no excursions during the next three. It is my idea that these coons will never kick against the british rule, they know when they are well off, and have never seen such prosperity as they are enjoying now.
Entry.37: We have to go through the whole syllabus of infantry training here, right from "Right Turn!" by numbers. It is very monotonous, and we hoped to get something fresh here. The picquet duty is finished tonight.
Entry.38: Had half a day off today; struck a good fatigue job; and Palmer and I got down into Cario. The more I see of this city the better I like it. The European quarter is very nice, with wide streets and gardens. We also inspected the native quarter and saw some surprising sights. Armed myself with a stout cane to keep off, the boot-blacks, beggars, and other pests. The evening’s amusement cost 5 piasters the cheapest I ever had. Got back to camp at midnight.
Entry.39: Paid 50 piastres. They have been well earnt. There is something to learn here for we were taught two new company movements today. One, "Artillery Formation", is good as it was born of expierence; the other "Forming Square" has given rise to the rumour that we are to go to the western desert to fight the Senuissi. Rumours are rife at present for the boys are in great form and are spoiling for a fight.
Entry.40:
No drill this morning. This afternoon, Palmer and I joined a party with a guide and went to see the historical sights of Cario. We visited a great many interesting places, including some of biblical fame. The Isle of Rodah where Moses was found

 

 

an old Coptic shrine above the spot where Mary and the Child were hidden. Different Mohammedan mosque’s of artitectural interest, including the Mosque of Amr, which has 365 pillars supporting it and they are all different. The Mosque of Hosean, that was built of marble stripped from the Pyramids The palace of the Sultan, and a dozen other places. Altogether, a great day.
Entry.41:
After Church Parade; I led some of the boys to the Pyramids. Climbed to the top of Cheops; only Palmer and I got there, for it is over 400 feet high; carved my name on the top as is the custom. Some of the dates there go back a hundred years. Then we crawled into the bowels of it and inspected the tomb from whence they dragged the remains

 

of the Pharoah, whose vanity caused this huge pile to be erected. It is a great mystery how they built it I give it up. The other two pyramids are smaller they are called Chepren and Mercereens. Then I observed and wondered at the supercilious expression of the Sphinx, that caused Napoloen’s artillerymen to try and blow its nose off. They made a mess of the Sphinx’ face but the expression won’t come off. And so home again after a ride on a camel.
Entry.42: Have joined the bombing class under Leiut Loveday. The work is interesting, and we have a saying that "a change is as good as a spell." We went down into the native gardens near Zeitoun for periscope practice today. Heard the song of the Camel Drivers.
Entry.43: Working with the bombing class today. We are nicknamed the "Suicide Club"; and it strikes me that a man will need plenty of sand to see this business through. Scottie came over from the Oasis where he is situated with the
Entry.44: A.L.H. We went to a concert, by the local talent.
Entry.45: Got a first class pass from the Bombing school, and a day off to go to Cario. Got an identification slip from Base Headquarters and went and drew £
Entry.46: from the bank. Visited the museum, and viewed many interesting relics. I saw a set of "diavals" that had been taken from some ancients tomb. I always thought it was a new game. Spent the rest of the evening in town, and did myself grand.
Entry.47: Got another all day pass, and went to Cario again. Spent the day in the city, went to a show had a good time generally. Back in camp at 11 P.M.
Entry.48: Slipped off to Heliopolis, and made myself comfortable in the soldiers club. Stayed there all day; came back to camp and was sitting on my angerib (a wicker bed) when Sep walked in. Gosh! I was pleased to see the priceless old feller. We went down into town and had a veritable corrobborre. He had some grand tales of Gallipoli, and I am going over to his unit the, Camel Corps tomorrow. We have been camped within a mile of one another for nearly a month and did not know it.
Entry.49: Went onto musketry today all the old stunts we did at Liverpool, except that they have a few pet flourishes here. Went down to Abassia and found Sep’s unit. Yarned with him a while, inspected his kit, camel, etc. then we went and had a beano at a dinkum eat-up joint in Heliopolis; struck Arch McIlveen there.
Entry.50: Woke up this morning to find that the company had been awarded 7 days pack drill! It appears that 3 chaps had a row with a Military Policeman; and the men got into our hut and he could not find them. Then he ran to the adjutant, with a cock and bull story, and he awarded us this punishment for something we know nothing of
Entry.51: Carried on the musketry today. This evening we were ordered to prepare our packs for our punishment drill. The company fell in with full marching order, at 5 PM. and demanded a inquiry. The adjutant rushed out and read the Riot Act, every man stood firm and demanded individually to be paraded before the Colonel. Was promised that we could see him tomorrow. Did an hour’s drill. Then was dismissed.
Entry.52: Saw the Colonel and the punishment was wiped out. Our company was detailed for inlying Picquet instead; so we don’t score much except that we brought the adjutant a crash. Sept came over to have a yarn.
Entry.53: The punishment was called right off today, so I was free to go down to Abassia to see Sep. He was on duty so we had a quiet yarn.
Entry.54: The C.O. had us out for Battalion drill today rather an interesting change. Then we did an attacking stunt far across the desert. Got back to camp and was picked for guard. This has spoilt my record for dodging guards.
Entry.55: Came off Guard and as it was St Pats’ day we had a half holiday. The M.P.s were busy catching the fellows who got to town too early; but I managed to get through to Abassia, then Arch Mc, Sep, and I had our photos taken in Heliopolis.
Entry.56: Was taken as escort for prisoners from the Kass-el-Nil Barracks to Gizerch There were about a hundred of them. It makes a man sick to have to escort a fellow Australian between fixed bayonets down the street. Rather a heavy day for it must be 9 miles to Gizerch.
Entry.57: There was some very heavy rain last night, an unusual thing for Egypt. Most of the chaps got wet, because the straw roofs would not keep the water out. I managed to keep dry. Sept and I went to the Zoogicial Gardens. They are situated at Gizerch and are absolutely the prettiest I have ever seen. The footpaths are made like a mosiaic of pebbles; a marvel of beauty and patience.
Entry.58: Had to pack up and shift down to the Kasr-el-Nil, barracks today. Marched out and got to the barracks at 11 A.M. We are to do Picquet duty in Cario. These barracks are said to have been built by Napoleon when he occupied Egypt. They are very extensive and could hold 5000 men I reckon.
Entry.59: This picquet seems to be a splendid job. I sit on a chair in the Café Petrograd for five hours drinking beers at the expense of the house; and that is my days work. I have discovered a home at last!! The other 19 hours I have to myself. I received some mail today, and I have leave for six hours tonight.
Entry.60: Struck Jack Moore today; he is a Segt Major in the Army Service Corps, and has just returned from Western Egypt. Was paid by Leiut Prescott. Saw Kirkland in the street.
Entry.61: Another General inspected us today. There seems to be a deuce of a lot of spare generals on this Egyptian staff. Shepherd’s Hotel was full of them the other day when General Maxwell was leaving for England, or some place. Spent the evening intown with Sep.
Entry.62: Everything quiet on the picquet. Have been transfered to Crotti’s Resturant; so now I have light refreshments at the expense of the house instead of beer. The amount of French pastry I can eat now is astonishing.
Entry.63: Ordered away from Kasr-el-Nil at 9 A.M. Marched 9 miles to Zeitoum via aerodrome; and entrained at 6 P.M. in open trucks. I guess it would do a N.S.W. railway commissioner a lot of good to have been with us in those trucks, the crush was indescribable. We start for an unknown destination at 10 P.M.
Entry.64: We travelled all night, and it was bitterly cold travelling beside the Nile. Arrived at Alexandria at 6 A.M; and immediately embark on the Transport. "Translyvania". Troops are arriving hourly and are pouring aboard this ship and others that are ling around the quays. The ship leaves the wharf and anchors in the stream. I saw a South African Regt. arrive.
Entry.65: The transport sailed at 10 A.M. Alexandria is a busy port crowded with ships. The ship is under convoy and the fact that we have to always wear our lifebelts remind us that we are in the war zone. The submarines are bad just about here.
Entry.66:
The torpedo boat "Rattlesnake" came alongside this morning, and we picked up our escort soon after; it is a small cruiser. I saw a fleet of minesweepers at work and the escort lead us through the swept area. We are sailing by a great mountainous island there is much snow on the tops of the mountains. A ships officer tells me it is the island of Crete. I looks very pretty this evening. 

a chap fell over board this evening and the ship did not stop until ordered to by the escort. The cruiser picked him up after a search and he died of exposure shortly after.
Entry.67: A beautiful day and the sea is calm and marvelously blue. This ship the "Transylvania" is was once a Cunard Liner; is about 19,000 tons, and is very fast, we must be averaging 17 knots. She is carrying 3500 troops; and numerous staff including, General Sir William Birdwood; Commander of the Anzac Corps and his staff. Which may account for the fact that we are sailing alone and at such high speed. The ship steers a zig-zag course; and we wear our life belts and stand by the boats all day I am stroke oar in No.12 boat. Sighted no today.
Entry.68: Our escort left us last night. A hazy day, and by the way the ship is trembling we are travelling at top speed. There was a church parade there were four Generals attending. General Birdwood inspected us, he seems a decent guy. Passed an island called "Montagne" a french convict settlement.
Entry.69: The island of Corsica was an the starboard side this morning. General Birdwood addressed us, and told some stories of Gallipoli and the Landing. He is well mannered towards us and wears a patch of service ribbons that commands respect. Because of the short rations on this ship we have nicknamed her "Starveania". But our trip is nearly finished now as we cannot be far from France.
Entry.71: We have been travelling for a whole day through the most enchanting scenery I have ever seen. I had not dreamed that anything could be so beautiful. It is spring time here and the orchards are in bloom; Such green grass, such blue sky and sea, it is great to rest one’s eyes on such a vivid contrast of colours after the burning desert sand of Egypt. It is good to see the smiling faces of the French people.They give us a great reception. A pretty, black-eyed mademoiselle, came to my carriage and distributed boquets of field flowers. One of the chaps asked her what she thought of Australian soldiers. She said we were like a lot of brigands ment as a complement I suppose, on our easy manners. We passed Lyons at 5 A.M. so leave the south of France behind us.
Entry.72: Passed through Paris at 3 A.M. Nothing to see as the city is in darkness. Passed old trenches and barb wire entanglements, that show where the tide of war has been. Went through Amiens at 12 Noon. It is decidedly wintery up here. It is a shock to see the amount of women that work in the fields here, there seem to be no one left but the women and old men. We reached our destination, a place call Etaples; by the English Channel at 4 P.M. Passed through the armoury after we detrained; then marched up to camp in the lines of an English bus Depot. There is camp here, and there are a score of field hospitals close about. There is a fair sized fishing village down by the river mouth went down and had a look round it.
Entry.73: I was a bitter cold night, with wind and rain. Busy settling down into camp routine. The camp commandant was to inspect us but the move fell through.
Entry.74: The inspection came off today, and he said the usual things when it was over. Then we went through a general medical inspection. An Aeroplane and and two Parseval Airships passed over the camp in company today.
Entry.75: The Australian units are ordered to be ready to move off to pitch a camp for themselves across the Railway line on the sand dunes. We were issued with a blanket and woollen underclothing against the cold which was very severe last night.
Entry.76: Cold and wet. We moved off at 2 P.M., and went and pitched a new camp on the Bolougne Road; beside a small creek. A new O.C. was attached today a cove named Bailey.
Entry.77: More rain and wet. The second Battalion came down today and we had to give up the tents we had pitched it was damn annoying. Located new tents, and slept all the afternoon. There was an issue of Rum the first since I joined; it was good for we are all feeling the cold intensely.
Entry.78: Had a short parade. A schooner went ashore up the coast last night, 3 of the crew were drowned. The rations are not so plentiful here. The Bread ration is 6 ozs a day.
Entry.79: Went on a route march through Etaples. This place has marvellously crooked streets, and a very fishy smell. The Bread ration was halved today only 3 ozs a man. We must have taken an enormous number of prisoners or something to cause the shortage.
Entry.80: Went to the training ground that our boys have nicknamed the "Bull Ring". An English Office took the company over and put us through our paces. I think we surprised him. Troop trains pass continually on the line to Bolougne. Some New Zealanders passed today. My company was passed as efficient today in the list at the Bull Ring, and do not need further instruction. This is rather a feather in our caps. But we will have to supply Guards etc.
Entry.81: The company works on fatigue, while the rest of the units complete their training. Saw a splendidly fitted Hospital Train today, it was presented by "Princess Christian" whoever she may be.
Entry.82: Two men less in the tent today the "Boob" has claimed them. The company went on a route march to "Paris Place", a pretty little watering place about 7 miles away, but is of course "out of bounds" to troops. Marched most of the way through thick pine woods. It was raining as usual; it is always raining here. Borrowed a boat and rowed across the estuary and spent the evening in "Paris Place" The Military Police guard the bridge. Palmer was with me.
Entry.83: Went on a washing parade to the Etaples laundry. Had my clothes washed in soda and soap, wished I could have got into the mixture myself. Bill Brew has been taken to join the Pioneer Battalion he is the first to leave my clique. Still Raining, we are lucky that we are camped on sand dunes. There is no mud.
Entry.84: Drew Gas helmets from the Quarter Master. Went to the "Bull Ring" for instruction in their use. They are very uncomfortable to wear at first and take some getting used to. For the flannel fabric they are made of is soaked in a strong solution of Hypo and ammonia, and the fumes are very strong. But they are invalueable so no one minds the discomfort.
Entry.85: Anzac Day. The Brigade marched out to a square field enclosed on three sides by pine woods; and there a memorial service was conducted. A very large number of our fellows were an parade there; a the whole parade gave the Royal Salute to the Memory of the Australian Dead. It was a very impressive ceremony.
Entry.86: There was a zeppelin raid on this base last night. The raider dropped nine large bombs, no damage was done; but a few casualities and large holes blown in the ground. One bomb fell about 150 yards away but failed to explode. I hopped out of my tent when I heard the racket and saw the "Zep" flying at an immense height. It disappeared straight away.
Entry.87: Aeroplanes were patroling last night, but the "Baby Killers" did not come again. Orders have been issued that all lights must be screened at night. The "Zepplin" has set them thinking. Spent the afternoon in Etaples.
Entry.88: Route marched to "Paris Place". This place looks as if it was built for scenes in a Theatre. Some of the quaintest artitecture is to be seen in the houses and shops. They are all quite new and are owned by a sydicate I believe. Got over the estuary again, and visited Paris Place this evening but was nearly "pinched" by the M.P.s. Had to swim back across the water. Some one had re-borrowed the boat. Shall have to be more careful.
Entry.89: Was sunbathing on the sand dunes all the morning. Went and tried my rifle on the range. It is a little beauty and worth caring for. I was in great form too and did exellent shooting.
Entry.90:
May.1916

Went on a swimming parade to "Paris Place". Rather an unusual season to be swimming in the English Channel. Was swimming round the wreck of the P.&G. steamer Scotra. Which was mined or torpedoed by the "huns" and run ashore. Evidently another ship was torpeoded near here lately for thousands of oranges are strewn along the coast. They are quite fresh and good. The rise and fall of the tide is extraordinary in these shallow seas.
Entry.91: Went to the "Bull Ring" and had instruction in grenades. Threw live Mills Hand Grenades and used rifle grenades. The hand grenades are peculiarly deadly; and it is a strange sensation to throw one for the first time. There was an accident with one today and the instructor and another was killed, and five were injured.
Entry.92: To the Etaples Steam Laundry for a bath, and to wash my clothes. A big Australian mail was distributed. A very popular day.
Entry.93: At the training ground today the company went through a sort of obstical race over high walls and trenches carring all our gear. Very strenuous.
Entry.94: Route Mached 10 Kilometres to the east of Etaples. The country is very pretty now for spring is well advanced. There are no fences round the farms here or hedges of any kind; I wonder how the farmers know their lands. There are no detached farms, for the farmers cluster in villages and hamlets, so these small villages are numerous. Observed the system of billeting troops. There is a regiment of British cavalry billeted in these hamlets. They say they have been there for many months. They are having an easy time at present for they are not called on to serve in the trenches now. Was paid 14/- when we returned. Went down to my Estaminet and spent some of this wealth.
Entry.95: Went to the training ground and did some Battalion drill under young English officers. Most of these English officers are very young and generally are not popular with our fellows; we call them "War Babies". The one that had my platoon today wore a "window in his eye"; but he seemed a decent sort of chap. It poured rain all day.
Entry.96:
We are all sick and tired of this ceaseless training, and there is no indication of a move to the trenches as yet, though all the fellows are in the pink of condition. There is a detention camp near here; where I saw men undergoing the punishment known as "Crucifiction". They are strapped to a beam with their arms stretched

above their heads for four hours each day. This cramped position is great torture I believe, especially in this biting wind. There is some complaint about Australian soldiers undergoing this punishment, while they are in British Detention camp; it is not allowed in the A.I.F.
Entry.97: Took rations and marched to a place called "Berke". A very long march. More Australian mail today. Leuit Lacy is now O.C. of the Company.
Entry.98: Field Marshal Sir Douglas Haig; Commander-in-Chief of the Army in France; visited us today and made a hurried inspection. He is a smart figure of a man; though rather small in statue. There were an enormous number of troops at the "Bull Ring" when he came.
Entry.99:
Received another issue of army tobacco it is of very fair quality this time. 

Washed clothes at the Laundry then went to the Tommies camp and had a "Russian Bath" in their steam house. It was a treat, the best bath I have had for a long time. I think it is a good omen, that we will not loiter here much longer. Futter has arrived from Egypt with artillery details. A letter form Sep, from El Alamien.
Entry.100: Got a good job as Divisional Orderly went on duty to Etaples after being paid 20 francs. Spent the afternoon there. Fell foul of "Charlie" the Sergt.Major; we clapped bills and he wanted to put me in the "clink"; came the old soldier stunt of complaining to the adjutant.
Entry.101: They seem to be at a loss to know what to do with us; for I reckon the drill of this company is perfect; they come to us for all the ceremonial parties now. Went for a march beyond "Camaires" a fair sized town along the Bolougne road. It is pleasant to march among the green woods and fields. Went rabbiting in the sand hills this evening, caught one big fellow. I suppose the next thing will be an order against poaching.
Entry.102: On duty as orderly to the quarter Guard, an easy job. There were any amount of aeroplanes about today; stunting about the sky. One takes no notice of them now, for aeroplanes and airships are to be seen any day now. One big British airship named "Silver Queen", patrols the coast regularly, spotting for "U" Boats.
Entry.103: There was a Muster Call this afternoon, and we doubled up thinking a move was right. Nothing doing, it was apparently a practical joke. By the movement on the railway that runs by the camp we will be busy enough before long. Saw a regiment of French soldiers they are fine amiable fellows. Of a good stamp physically and nearly all cultivate fierce beards; they are called "les piolu" for that reason I am told. We were amazed at the clean shaven faces of our chaps. They said they were off to the Verdun sector.
Entry.104:
Was on guard yesterday and "Charlie" the D.S.M. tried to cross my beat, I wheeled him and he went crook; so I took this heaven sent opportunity to tell him what I

thought of him; he told me to consider myself under arrest, then I jerked a cartridge into the funnel and ordered him to clear out. Reported it to the Orderly officer, and beat him again. Then some Anzacs who arrived from England this afternoon "counted him out". He is making himself unpopular.
Entry.105: Got over to Paris Place again today got caught by the incoming tide, so had to go round by the bridge under the noses of the "Jack". Luck carried me through again. The boys are annoyed at the new company commander, and told him so. Don’t know his name, we call him "Cuckoo". He is a typical text book officer. We greeted his remark that the "Book says"; with a broad smile.
Entry.106: Went with 18 other chaps to the "Bull Ring" and did sundry courses. The Australian division made a demonstration tonight with mines, artillery, rockets, and other "property". I suppose this is the grand final, as a draft is leaving for the forward area tomorrow. All cameras in the possession of the troops were seized today and all diaries and other writings were ordered to be handed in. I will risk it with this one, I guess.
Entry.107:
On fatigue storing things at the Quarter Master’s store. Met Alf Morey the boxer chap there. Was riding on a wagon with a "Tommy" driver, and he tipped

the thing clean over. I nearly went under the load. Some of these English A.S.C. couldn’t drive a tack.
Entry.108: Oh! Day of Days! The company was warned to be in readiness to proceed to the forward area. Went under a medical examination. Several fellows were rejected. Drew shortages of kit from the Quarter Master Sergeant. Had to pay for a towel I had lost. What sort of a turn out is this where a man has to pay for his worn out kit after 10 months service and no new issues? Paraded in all our kit; did not mind it this time, now that we are pronounced fit for war. No one could look at this company of splendid fellows and think otherwise. Went down with Palmer, to the Café Les Voyageurs and cracked a bottle of champagne.
Entry.109: Reveille at 2 A.M. Marched out of camp, and entrained at Etaples. It was my first ride in the truck marked "Hommes 40. Chevoux 8". Travelled via Bolougne & Calais. Did not travel very fast. "Bluey" McMasters fell out of the train and had time to run after it and catch up. Arrived at the railhead, about 3 P.M. Detrained and marched to where the Battalion is in reserve to the "Bailly" sector. Am billeted in a deserted farm house, not far from the firing lines, as I can see all the flares that illuminate "No Mans Land" at night. The Germans are using a curious rocket far behind their line. They look like strings of flares and they rise to a great height. The front seems quiet and is nothing like what I expected to see. A dispatch rider has arrived with orders for us to go and reinforce the
Entry.111: Marched down to Head Quarters and were inspected by a gay old joker named Brig.Gen. Foot. He told us the order about the 11th Batt is cancelled. We are greatly relieved. Was ordered to join the 3rd Battalion. Reported to the 3rd Battalion H.Q, in the afternoon. Several officers inspected us there and put us through our paces for about an hour. We had quite an audience in the finish for I reckon we showed them what a real reinforcement company was like. Then the boys were distributed over the whole Battalion and the good old 14/3 was no more. Palmer and I were sent to 16 Platoon D. Company. It was dark when we got to the billets and there was no one about. Lay down in the straw; we got a duece of a ragging when the mob came in after the pubs shut. They wanted to know "how we came to hear about the war"; In a physical arguement I got a black eye.
Entry.112: As all the boys were sober, they were more amiable this morning. Except for my eye, there is nothing to show for the initiation ceremony of last night. I did not expect to find booze in the reserve lines; but a few of we "reinfo" took our Platoon Sergeant; Harry Parker, is his name and bought him lots of beer. Now everything is all right. This company has none of the "spit and polish" of the 14/3; all the fellows in it seem to drink and swear hard and the fact that we are "D" Company; of the "Incomparable Fighting Third," goes to prove that they will fight like 14 devils. This evening we marched up to support in the "Fleurbaix" sector; and made ourselves snug in a billet about 2 miles from the firing line. Marching in the ranks of a fighting Battalion has made this one of the proudest days of my life.
Entry.113: A quiet night. Today there does not seem to be a war on at all. The fact that we stay under cover as much as possible; alone, goes to show that the Huns are within range of us. We were detailed into fatigue and carring parties for the ‘line’ I go up tonight.
Entry.114: Went out to the firing line last night. Received my baptism of fire, in a strafe that was going on. It was the healthiest fright I have ever had in my life. I lay in a stinking drain, almost entirely submerged in mud and water for a quarter of an hour, while shells shrieked and crashed and machine gun bullets mowed the grass about six inches above my head. One of the party was wounded before we finished the job. Got back to billet, covered with mud, at 3 A.M.
Entry.115: Cold and Wet. Worked on the tram-line from "Tin Barn Dump". Was caught in the open by another bombardment and sought the protection of my friend the ditch again. Did not mind it this time for our guns opened up and gave him beans; which was very comforting. The crossfire of his machine guns was very hot. There were no causualities. The peasants in this part of the world wear big wooden shoes, shaped like pontoons, and because of the amount of rain that falls in this region, I reckon they need them, the mud and slush is a caution, a man could drown in it; and splashing through it makes a man so tired, that I can throw myself down on the stone floors of my billet, and sleep in my saturated clothes like someone dead.
Entry.116: More rain, More wet, a whole week of it. Was working in the "Dead Dog Avenue" trench last night. We always sleep fully dressed; but tonight we are on the "Qui Vive" for some reason or other. There is to be a "strafe" I suppose. The "daylight saving" scheme comes in tonight; it won’t effect us much who work at night.
Entry.117: Fritz blew over a little gas attack last night, but it missed our sector. Our "heads" must have known; hence the warning. Our guns were very active, during the night, sending over a protest. Did duty as billet guard, and gas sentry; to warn the company of gas attacks, shells, and other annoyances that the hun is liable to send over anytime. An easy day. Paid 14/-.
Entry.118: Went to work at 7.A.M. this morning. Came back to billet at 1 P.M.; out to the line at 9.P.M. everything was quiet, back again at 3.A.M. Was building a dressing station. Witnessed a splendid air duel between four British planes and three Taubes. The Taubes were driven down.
Entry.119: As Sunday is our busy day, we went to the firing line via "Dead Dog Avenue", and worked. "B" Company’s billet was destroyed by Fritz’s guns this afternoon and all our tools were destroyed. We’ll soon get plenty more. A French civilian warned some of the chaps that the place would be blown up today; these civilians round here know too much; and I believe they would sell their soul for a franc. They all ought to be cleared right out of the fighting zone.
Entry.120: Worked in the line until 12 Noon. got back, to find that orders were out for us to relieve "B" Coy from close Supports, that they might be re-equipped. Dug new trenches and occupied them; or rather repaired old ones. As there is no shelter this is a comfortless hole.
Entry.121: Have digged a dugout, and have shelter of sorts. We were shelled vigoursly with 5 inch shells; they tore the ground up a bit but no one was hurt. Some of the chaps were out searching for nose-caps, as souvenirs. Don’t do anything here except keep our heads down.
Entry.122:
Fairly rained 59 shells today. Fritz sent over hundreds of shells at a battery a few hundred yards in our rear. We had an anxious time while he was

searching for the range. Dirt flew over us in showers. We all breathed easier when he got set, though showers of debris came over us continually. He shelled everything in the vincinity but the guns were not put out of action. It was laughable to see the gunners scampering away from their position. A liberty the infantry do not possess. Received some mail.
Entry.123: Not so many shells today a few fell about. Went up to releive the front line this evening. The releif was carried out swimmingly and without hitch. In my section of the line I occupy a dugout, measuring 6ft by 2ft with Wallace. Thanks to our labours during the previous weeks the line is in exellent repair. There was a thunder storm this evening.
Entry.124: The line here is a high breast work. Trenches being impossible because water is only 18 inches down. The breast work is very strong but a lot of labour is necessary to keep it in repair. I am on post observing the enemy line for four hours each night, and do fatigue in my spare time. The hun trenches are four hundred yards from this point, and our line is protected by a belt of barbed wire thirty feet thick. So I feel pretty comfortable.
Entry.125: A quiet Day. I saw 10 of our aeroplanes up at once. They attacked the enemy observation balloons with patent bombs and burnt four of them. There is an airman on this front, popularly know as the "Mad Major", he seems to be the last word in fearlessness.
Entry.126: There was a big "strafe" last night with artillery. The din was terrific. I was nearly skittled by a shell that burst directly in front of me; within three feet of my face as I stood observing over the parapet. Was stunned and blinded for a while, but soon recovered. Received some newspapers.
Entry.127: A fine day with a overcast sky. Our planes again attacked the german balloons and destroyed three of them. Our boys cheered when they fell. Fritz’s evening "hate" was rather prolonged today.
Entry.128:
Our trench mortars sent over some favours to the huns this morning but he seem peeved about the frightful

 

destruction they were causing in his trenches; and he opened up with his guns and tore the landscape about considerably. The rations are good here and we are able to get hot meals, for which Allah be praised!
Entry.129: Yesterday we suffered a terrific bombardment. The worst we have had yet. Our guns were active also and blasted the german trenches with a hurricane of fire. There is something unusual in the wind, for there are curious preparations going on; our rifles and ammunition have to be kept copiously oiled, and gas helmets are worn in the "alert" position. A squadron of 20 of our aeroplanes disappeared over the hun lines this evening. The most I’ve ever seen at one time. There will be a hot time in Hunland tonight.
Entry.130:
July.1916.

Went out in front with a "wiring party" last night; repairing the wire entanglements in front. It passed off all night, though the enemy’s fire quickend a lot after we came in. The air squadron that passed yesterday evening returned this morning. A "Taube" attacked 7 of our planes today; but was driven off. It is said that it was Immelmann, the "Eagle of Lille". His "stoop" was unsuccessful anyway.
Entry.131: I am sleeping under the stars while my portion of the trench is being repaired. The Wide Heaven is no cover for a man these stirring times. I miss my little 6 x 2 dugout when Fritz’s shrapnel is bursting over the trench. I am to go out on patrol at 11 P.M. A risky business, so I will leave this book with Wallace.
Entry.132: Crept about in No Mans’ Land for an hour. We captured a Hun sniper, who has been troubling us for some time, he dropped from a willow tree almost on top of one of our chaps, who was armed to the teeth, but he forgot about all his lethal weapons, and punched the Hun in the eye, then gave him a shower of uppercuts that knocked him out. He was a Bavarian a rough looking joker too; dressed in tweed trousers and a blue butchers coat. As we were returning to our lines a machine gun caught us and one of our chaps was killed. This machine gun is operated by the crack German gunner on this front. He is known as "Parapet Joe" and I must say that if he could express his talent on a violin he would be called a genius. A very wild night, shells of every calibre rained down on our line.
Entry.133: The daytime is quiet here except for the regular doses of "Hate" that we receive from Fritz at 7 A.M. and 5 P.M. or thereabouts. He threw a lot of heavy stuff over onto some place in the rear; he has succeeded in setting fire to something by conflagration I can see. During my shift last night I got onto "Parapet Joe’s" emplacement; and kept firing at it till he got real mad and kept his gun firing on my bay for about five minutes. Have got my gear together for we are to be releived tonight.
Entry.134: The 45th reliveed us; their first time in the line, and the releif took some time. Marched through pouring rain to billets near Sailly-sur-Lys. The march was very fatiguing otherwise the releif was uneventful.
Entry.135: Route Marches are the order of the day here, I suspect that they are getting us set for a long march somewhere. Had a foot inspection and a bath (I needed the bath) this afternoon. Met Sergt Major Jack Moore, and Sgt Chisholm today. There are cherry trees loaded with fruit here and I pay them considerable attention.
Entry.136: Had another good bath today. There are three things a man looks forward to here; a bath, a pay, and a good night’s sleep. Our Company Commander Captain Harris; (we call him "Digby") warns us to be ready for the road tomorrow. "Digby" is a god old sport, he buys us beer, plum puddings,and other comforts. A sure road to the hearts of the troops.
Entry.137: Paraded in full marching order at 8 A.M. Marched all the morning covered some 9 miles. We have halted at a billet near Merrio and we march on again tomorrow. Whither we are bound I know not.
Entry.138: Did not get our blankets last night, the transport that is carrying them has moved on; but it was warm enough in the straw of the barn. Rested here all day waiting for the order to move. It will come some time tonight I suppose. Marched off at 11.P.M.
Entry.139:
Marched 5 miles last night, to the railway at Bailleul. Entrained 40 in a truck. Journeyed for some hours and detrained at a nameless

 

station. Marched 10 miles or so to a town called, Saint Guen. A nice little town; there has never been any Australians here before hence the surprise of the natives. The boys are taking this opportunity to enjoy themselves, for there is much innocent amusement and good liquor to be had here.
Entry.140: Again an early start, but we only went a few kilos, to another town called Vignacourt. Here I am billeted in the "Billet Ideal". There are chairs and tables and pictures on the wall. The "Madame" of the place is O.K. too, the one in our last place was a veritable Fury. She told us; or rather our Captain, that we were worse than the Germans, because we washed in her horse trough. What would she say if we burned her house.
Entry.141: Left Vignacourt at midday we got three minutes notice. This was a nice, clean, little town; and the people too seemed to be more intimate with soap than the Flemish. Covered 12 miles, and the battalion is camped in an old aeroplane hangar near Allonvillle. It is such a crush that many of the boys are sleeping on the grass.
Entry.142:
Have rested here a couple of days. Did a bit of field work in a pretty little wood nearby; where violets grow in profusion, much larger than our violets but like them have no scent. Some French anti-aircraft shells fell around this evening. One came through

 

the shed where I am lying and buried underneath me, but, fortunately it was a "dud" and did not explode. I wrote some letters in these unhealthy surroundings.
Entry.145: Battalion’s busy day, so we rolled "Matilda" and hoofed it away from Allonville. Left Amiens in the valley through which the "Somme" flows and marched out along the Albert Road to Warloy, were we got quarters in a deserted farm. We may spend a few days here, it will be alright for this one horse joint boasts of a B.E.F. Canteen. We are not far from the front here, it is a very active one too for the gun fire is continuous, and very heavy stuff too.
Entry.146: They took our blankets today and there has been much inspection of gear and equipment. We have to stand by ready to move off at half an hours notice. We get plenty of that sort of thing. Old "Digly" gave us his views and instructions concerning the fighting we may get mixed up in. All we ask is; Lead us to it;
Entry.147:
Muster Parade today. 16 Platoon is 75 strong. We were issued with large patches of pink cloth to sew on our backs. A careful inspection followed. This afternoon we marched out through Albert. We are resting in a field now, alongside the road that leads to the front; English troops are passing back along the road

they are nearly all wearing German spiked helmets, and tell tales of terrific fighting. We passed a church in Albert that the Huns have destroyed it must have been a magnificent place. We have left our packs and over-coats stored in Warloy, and are in very light fighting order. Received a lot of mail you today.
Entry.149:
Kings Royal Rifles, opposite the village of "Pozieres," which the Germans hold. There has been terrific fighting about here, and this battlefield is a dreadful spectacle, for the dead still lie unburied. The trenches here are very rough. I was detailed off this morning with a party of 50 other chaps to go to "Gordon’s Dump", on carrying fatigue. Carrying ammunition, rations, and

 water to the firing line. The work is very hard, for the roads we travel are continously swept by shell fire; and we suffer loss that makes our burden heavier. 15 were knocked in my party today. It is about two miles up to our forward dump. Half the way is along Sausage Gully and is exposed to his observation and fire.
Entry.150:
Yesterday and last night I did 7 trips to the forward dump. We have lost more than half our party so the loads are heavier, as the stuff must go up. I do not duck from the shells now. The sight of these stretcher-bearers carring out the wounded, would make anyone walk upright. They are heroes those splendid fellows. I get very

little sleep an less to eat. My feet are swollen and blistered for I have no soap to treat them with. They are very painful. My party has made a forward dump of 200,000 rounds of ammunition, 5000 boxes of bombs, 2000 gallons of water, and rations for the brigade, and various other stores. And there are those who lie beside the truck with their loads who will never carry again. The Brigade attacks in the morning, and I shall go over the top with them. If this book is returned to you; Remember that I would not be elsewhere, than with these men you will be so proud of.
Entry.151:
The Brigade advanced about a 1000 yards before daylight this morning. Capturing the village

of Pozieres; and I got forward on the left to a small wood; where the fellows dug in. There was not much fighting here for the Germans did not stand. Helped dig the trenches then was ordered back to the carrying work. I had a shot at some Huns that were scuttling away. just before I left, and it releived my feelings a lot. There seems to be double the amount of material to carry now; I won’t last much longer, I am utterly worn out.
Entry.152: Returned to the trenches last night where our boys are holding the ground gained. The 2nd Brigade has sent a party to work on the dump. The Huns have started a heavy bombardment of our position
Entry.153: Have been under a terrible bombardment for three days now. Our trench has disappeared and we are holding on in shell holes. Have advanced in front of his barrage and are better off here. Have no food or water. Don’t know where the Battalion is. Was buried by a shell yesterday Palmer dug me out. He is not with me now.
Entry.154:
Last night we were relieved by the 5th Brigade. Found my way back to Becourt Wood. I found Palmer there he has a slight wound in the head. The cooks gave me a grand hot meal and I had a good sleep

All the chaps are utterly worn out; it sure was a big stunt. Many of the fellows are missing but they will doubtless turn up tomorrow. We will move off this evening.
Entry.155:
The mob were singing as they marched through Albert last night. Bivouaced on the heights behind the town; where we got overcoats and lay down till daylight. Then I noticed that the chaps were gravely saluting me, and discovered that I was wearing some Captain’s overcoat with three stars on the shoulder straps. I have been a captain for nonce. We had a roll call; 16 Platoon mustered 23 men. Then we marched on to camp in the wood at Contay. There

was great shaking of hands amongst us for we have been through Hell. Both Generals Walker and Birdwood came to see us. Birdwood congratulated us on the work we did; he says that a British regular division that was on our right said they were "proud to fight beside us"; we did give the hun a nasty jolt in wresting such a strong key position from him. I washed my face and hands, the first time for a Week
Entry.156: Started away again this evening and marched 10 miles. The transport took our packs but many of the fellows were too weak to march and ambulances picked them up. I don’t wonder now why a man needs to be highly trained to stand up to this job. It tried me out this time for my feet are very sore.
Entry.157: On again today till we came to Bonneville. Halted here and I went and had a swim in a stream. The first good wash I have had for many moons. I feel much better now. This town is not much chop.
Entry.158: Today we reached our destination a place called Pernois. I have a good billet so I won’t mind staying here. The country is very pretty in this region; Picardy it is called I beleive. We had a church parade, it was more like a memorial service. We have lost many of our comrades, but they have died even as I would die. Our Colonel seemed very upset; he is a fine young fellow only 23 years old.
Entry.159: Commenced our "Rest?" with the usual syllabus of infantry training. Our acting O.C. is not popular, so things are not as pleasant as they might be. It is very pleasant here surrounded by woods and a small river running past.
Entry.160: Have been drilling hard all the week. Went on a long route march today. Old "Digby" came back this morning he looks none the worse for his shell shock. We gave him a cheer for we are all pleased to see him back. There a two very nice old French people in this billet, their daughter is very nice too. I am well in with them, and often take "coffee royal" with them. Was issued with a shirt and received a lot of mail this week.
Entry.161: Did guard yesterday, and got another fist full of letters from home. A young soldier has come to visit the old people who live here, he is a Chasseur, and wears a gorgeous uniform of blue, red, and silver. He is from the Verdun front he says; and has taken possession of "Yvonne" in a way that makes us fit to bite our tongues with envy. Had a bit of a field day, today; the colonel reckoned we show a vast improvement, so we shall not "Rest?" much longer now
Entry.162: Packed up and march off at 9.00. It was hot and after a rotten march we got to this ranch where we are bivouacked in an apple orchard for the night. We were issued with clasp knives.
Entry.163: There was rain today, and we marched through it to Herissart, where we went into billets. It is a fair sized place this with a canteen. We are permitted to write letters so will probably stay here a few days. Our boys seem to be popular with the garrulous old froggie that owns this joint. He showed us with much gesture with a rifle he borrowed; how he killed a Garman in 1870. One of the other fellows rode a colt he said was a bit of a buckjumper; and he was amazed to see the Aussie ride it barebacked. Captain Harris’s nerves are still bad, and he does not seem well, so the colonel has sent him to a job in the D.A.C. or something.
Entry.164:
A Brigade Church Parade today. General Birdwood was present, and 

he presented several men with the Military Medal ribbons; it was beyond his power to give medals he said. There were two men of the
Entry.165: Battalion decorated, both of "D" Coy. The Company has now, one V.C., two D.C.M.’s, and two M.M.’s We got the "straight griffin" from Birdwood, he says there will be no rest for anyone while the "push" is on. He uses some very endearing terms, this fellow; today he called us his; "Dear old First Brigade, the boys with hearts of gold";. The chaps don’t like this sort of thing; but I think he is a good General.
Entry.166: Parades as usual in the morning. We received our overdue pay, and then we marched to Contay and camped at the wood. Rained all day.
Entry.167: Left Contay yesterday morning and marched through Albert, a pipe band of the Gordon Highlanders play ahead of my platoon as we marched through the town. Rested some hours in the reserve line. Cold and raining. Then went over a terrible track to the front line, reaching it in the daylight. Of the Pozieres village not a trace remains, and this position on the left of the windmill overlooks Courcelette, so some one has been working while we were away. There is a good deal of shelling going on but happily not much comes our way. I got a bit of sleep in a Hun dugout. There were some very dead huns in it but I did not mind. They had a tunnel to a machine gun emplacement thirty yards long.
Entry.168: It continues to be fairly quiet Fritz pays more attention to the communications in the rear, of the part we occupy. The trenches are of a rough and ready character here, they have been knocked about by the artillery of both sides; still they serve; although obliterated in places. We get much more duty now being so much under strength.
Entry.169:
Had rather a trying time last night. Was lying out on the top of the parapet observing, under heavy fire for four hours; it gave me the "Willies" properly. One of his "Pip Squeak" guns was playing right at me for half an hour and gave me a bad attack of "Wind Up". Never got a scratch however. "B" Company has been

cut up by our own guns, so we had to move down to the left this after-noon, to shorten our line. Our guns gave us a salvo too and killed some of 13 Platoon. Some one ought to be shot over this; for we cannot stop them. We are in a very exposed position here, if we are shelled no one will survive. Percy Wright was killed last night.
Entry.170:
Had another thrill last night went and lined the front parapet in preparation for an attack on Moquet Farm. The stunt was cancelled at the last moment. The Hun cannot know we are here for we have not received a single shell in this trench. He is sending them into the rear of us, hot and heavy. We have fooled

him I think. We were relieved in daylight this evening. The Huns must have seen us, for they gave us "hurry up" all the way out. This trip did not last long, but it was thrilling enough. Being releived on the aniveserary of joining made the event popular.
Entry.171: We are in billets in Albert; we got here last night; it saved my life. I had no sleep for 3 nights, but I had a splendid sleep today; and received a big mail, so everything is bright and beautiful again.
Entry.172:
Broke into the cellar of a ruined house yesterday and found a lot of wine. I lead my braves to it and we finished the lot before we left for Warloy 

today. It was a piece of gorgeous luck; and I am very popular today; if I do say it myself.
Entry.173: Reached Val-de-Maison, yesterday and a few details joined us there. A Brigade parade this afternoon at Savigcone. Birdwood came to issue D.C.M.s to those who distinguished themselves. The Third Battalion got 3, D.C.M’s and the Doctor got the Military Cross.
Entry.174: Did a stiff march today, but as there was some rain last night the roads were good. This place is called Gezaincourt. We have struck a fair billet, though it is very verminous and has an extraordinary collection of odours, even for France and that is saying something.
Entry.175: We did not do much today so most of the boys found time to go and get drunk. "Digly" arrived back today, and ordered a muster parade this afternoon. He was disgusted he said; to see the whole company drunk. I borrowed five francs of him on the strength of being sober, and helping him with his horse. Will go to town this evening for we move very early in the morning and by the look of it no one will sleep much.
Entry.176: Marched off at 3.A.M. Covered some distance to Doullens and entrained in horse trucks that had not been cleaned; they were filthy with manure Journeyed for some hours; passed many coal pits. Detrained at Popperinghe. Marched about four Miles to Toronto Camp.
Entry.177: We are fairly comfortable here and have been doing the usual parades. Yesterday the official news was read saying that Roumainia had entered the field on the side of the allies. Cheers! We are in Belgium now; the remarkable flatness of the country is very noticeable. The leaves are falling from some of the trees; and it continues to rain with the steadiness that makes me think we will need an issue of lifebelts shortly. Have received much mail lately. Our hut leaks too much to allow writing here.
Entry.178:
The weather cleared today. Had a muster Parade, where the Coonel gave us some fatherly advice. This evening we were conveyed by train to Ypres; from there we

went to a position called "The Bund." Releived the Royal Irish Rifles. I have a good shelter here. There is a branch of the Y.M.C.A, near; the first one I have ever seen in a dugout.
Entry.179: Moved up nearer the line yesterday from here we will do carring fatigue for Engineers, Rations, etc. I have a good shelter, with bunks, etc. that some wag has named "Rat Villa". The rats are very troublesome at night; for they crawl all over one; and fight on the floor. I’ll back them to eat a hole through any thing; and some of them are an enormous size. There are some Canadians working near; they are characters. Some of their expressions are too droll for words. Fritz snipes at us with "77" guns here.
Entry.180: Have an enormous amount of work to do here. They have promised us that this will be our winter quarters; and as the trenches are in a disgusting state we will have to fix them up, in the way we know how. Fritz "strafes" us a good deal with "minnewerfers"; as he calls his large trench mortars. These bombs make a terrific explosion; for they weigh about 100 pounds; I can see them coming too and that makes them hard to get used to.
Entry.181: Went up to the front line trenches this morning and took over. The lines are close here between 30 and 40 yards apart. We are on "Hill 60" there has been terrific fighting here at times. It is very quiet now however.
Entry.182: It is creepy work observing at night with the lines so close that I can here the Boeches talking in their trench. They have a rifle fixed on this bay too it nearly got me last night the bullet struck the bag I was observing over and filled my eye with dirt. There is no place to sleep here and as the trench is full of muck we are in for a rough time. He only "hates" us with "minnenwerfers" and rifle grenades so things are quiet. We use the periscope on the day posts. A hun surrended with the information that the troops opposite have come from the "Somme Front" too. So the sector is quiet.
Entry.183: Was releived this evening. Have a good possie in Reserves, so here goes for a good sleep.
Entry.184: Yesterday I had a good rest, a wash and a shave. Feel a new man. We may not expose ourselves here for the Hun will see us and turn on the frightfulness. We do fatigue at night and so keep out of mischief. We get hot meals at night now.
Entry.185: Completed a new trench today, because of its odour we christened it "No4711" "Digly bought us some puddings today. He is a good poor beggar; it must cost a slug to by puddings for a Company. He promoted a sandbag filling competition in the Coy. The winning pair filled 34 bags and stacked them in 15 minutes. Saw Bill Brew working near with the1st Pioneer Battalion. Between the lot of us we have done wonders here and have made a beautiful position.
Entry.186: We were releived last night and came right back via the railway train to Halifax Camp. Did not get up till 11 o’clock. Then I went for a stroll this evening and had a good time in a neighbouring village; there were some jolly girls there. As usual a big mail was waiting for me.
Entry.187: Went looking for a fatigue job yesterday spent the day looking for it. Found it just when it was time to knock off. Marched to the
Entry.188: Divisional Baths and had a splendid Bath and a fumigation received a change of underclothes, after wearing the same shirt for 6 weeks. Was innoculated against some disease or other. I have all ready been dosed against every one I can think of. I drew a pass and went to Popperinghe.
Entry.189: Drilling about the place is the order of the day. I drew a new Box respirator today, they are a vast improvement on the old one. I am taking an interest in the Lewis Machine Gun; it is interesting and will releive the monotony. We have been issued with Anti Frost Bite grease to rub on our feet to prepare them for the winter. Received much mail, it is the only thing that makes this life bearable.
Entry.190: We were paid 14/-. As the weather cleared, we practised a little with the new Box helmets. The 3rd Battalion had sports this afternoon. General Plumer commanding the
Entry.191: Army was present. It was decent of him not to make us parade to him. He wore a monocle, this old geezer, and looked so quaint.
Entry.193: Battalion held a well organised sports meeting this afternoon and there will be a good concert tonight. 16 Platoon has a new officer, called Howard he is a character, too.
Entry.194: Brigade Church Parade at Busseboom. Birdwood issued some more Military Medals and, D.C.Ms. He brought Andy Fisher along with him, and there was the usual loads of "staff". "Birdie" had his usual chat; but Andy spared us his speech. Went for a Bath.
Entry.195: Spent the day packing up and getting ready to go to the line. Of course we had to leave the billets scrupulously clean; it is the trade mark of the
Entry.196:
Battalion. 

Marched off this evening; we have collected a band, and they led the way to the train. The old "rattler" conveyed us to a certain point, then we marched across country through hedges and across ditches till we came to this place; where I am living under the Lille Road. The
Entry.197: Brigade were here. They are a good mob to come in after.
Entry.198:
Was posted as ""Gas Guard", over a huge Strombos Horn, in the grounds of a fine Chateau, now more or less ruined. We call it "Bedford House". By the neglected ponds and gardens it seems to have been a fine place. But now the fine oak trees are splintered with shells and its rose garden is a cemetery. About 3.A.M. some one started a gas alarm.

Then all along the front arose the most dreadful din I ever heard hundreds of horns were blowing and bells ringing, other noise making instruments going strong. I turned the screw on my Strombos Horn; and it immediately set up a frightful bellow. Then I rushed along the shelters waking the chaps by shouting; "Gas! Put your helmets on!" I was a false alarm however; someone got the wind up about the rising mist I suppose.
Entry.199:
Working, fixing up the train line that runs along this road. I witnessed an air battle in which both combatants fell inside our lines. The German was flying one of our machines, so he caught 

our airman at a disadvantage. A quiet day generally. One of the chaps found some German newspapers in a field. I got a piece. They were dropped from a Taube I suppose. This is the reserve line here, so we will have to work for some days. Without a doubt the shovel is mightier than the sword in this section.
Entry.200:
Busy bagging up farm houses and making tramlines with them. We can easily put a farm house in bags when, the Huns have finished with it. The heads are much interested in our feet lately and try to kid me to dress them with some noisesome preparation made with whole oil. It does more harm than good. Dry socks is the solution

of the wet feet problems. Got into an argument with the Brigade Major today he reckons he will break me. This is the sort of thing a man has to stand from these fellows; while he is tempory-acting-Lance-Corpral; by the Grace of God. A gun we call "Quick Dick" was playing on the road today; he made our work more exciting than usual.
Entry.201:
Was releived of my command over the braves who are building the "C" tramline; went on a new fatigue to "Chester farm". Stacked a lot of material and got away early. Picked blackberries within four hundred yards of the front line, as I returned to my little home under the Lille road. There was a "gas alarm" last night I put my helmet on and went to sleep

in it. Wonder that I did not choke. The artillery of both sides was unusually active today.
Entry.202: We have been receiving reinforcements lately; we need them to. Went up to the big mine crater near the Yser Canal. This is a "whopper" crater. Have an elaborate plan of defences to carry out here, so will be employed for a while in the crater. "Hinie" only strafes us with rifle grenades at times so with a bit of luck we will have a good time one thing is certain, that no damn Brigade Major will come fussing round here. The Yser Canal is a fine stretch of water here because of the lock that is in it just "inside" our line. It is not long since this same canal was red with blood. Returned home via "Thames Trench" and the "Bluff".
Entry.203: The Bosche evidently objects to our unwonted activity in the crater and today he poured an unusual amount of rifle grenades and hate into our position so we left early. Coming home I caught a pheasant in a blackberry hedge. He was not very fat I suppose he was worried. The grounds round here are supposed to belong to King Albert of Belgium, so I can say I have eaten one of the Royal Pheasants. We received a rum issue. A good day.
Entry.204:
Was paid 20 Fr. yesterday. Working on the "S.O.S." trench till 1300. Packed up this evening and went up to the line taking over "32.R;" trench. All these trenches are new ones built by our chaps; they 

are the last word in comfort. I could stay here for the duration of the war. Those trenches that have crisp business like names are all our own make those called after someones fancy are the old ones. There is the "Orange Grove," "Fir Avenue," "Lovers Lane," "Batchelors Walk" I am all admiration for the English and Canadians who fought for these heights in 1914-15. This section is know as the "Bluff"; the trenches are from 30 to 50 yds apart. The situation is similar in every respect to "Hill 60" except that we are very comfortable.
Entry.205:
Yesterday Fritz’s gunners drew an extra allowance of shells, and strewed them over our sector liberally. There was a bit of a thrill this evening when it was ascertained that the Huns had a big mine set under our

position. It is knowledge that sort of makes ones toes tingle. We have our extra hour’s "stand-to" night and morning in case he fires it off and tries to rush us. It is a very unpleasant prospect no matter how I look at it.
Entry.206: Our pet mine has not exploded yet; and I still manage to sleep sweetly on top of it. Have been building a dressing station. Near Batt H.Q. I feel better down there, am not afraid to tread heavily. Hope "Hinie" nurses her a little longer for:- Hush!
Entry.207:
Went to No Mans land and assisted in a "Trench Raid." Did not get into the German trench; the fellows who did caused some distruction. There was no information gained for one of our chaps killed the 

 "evidence"; as he was bringing him back over No Man’s Land. I reckon raids are a useless business anyway. Was relieved this evening by the 14th Battalion. I was pleased to skip off the top of that mine. Boarded the "rattler" in Ypres; marching through the Lille Gate and through the town. This city has been utterly destroyed; I could not have imagined such a scene of indescribable destruction.
Entry.208: Reached Halifax Camp in the Dominion Lines early this morning had a few hours sleep, a tot of rum, and a snack. Then marched off at 9.00 did about 10 miles. Camped the night near Steenvoorde, which is just on the Frontier. Captain J.R.O. Harris, alias Digby rejoined us today. Will go and forage this evening.
Entry.209: An early start, did a god 12 miles and billeted near the village of Aneeke. Passed a very picturesque village today, quite the prettiest I have ever seen called Cassel. It is perched high on a hill; and its quaint red roofs and towers make it look like the coloured pictures of fairy cities. Beside it is the ruin of a grand old castle. Its great thick walls still standing, and its towers covered with ivy. A very charming country altogether. Passeded the evening in town, a very good place for tucker, and other comforts; a pleasant day! A pleasant world! Returned to camp and got a new blanket; have two now; am going to doss on the grass tonight.
Entry.210: A stiff march today, about 20 miles. All the way we passed through charming scenery. If Picardy is is pretty in the Summer time; this Department-de-Calais is beautiful in the Autumn. Marched though the large village of Watten. Passed another large castle; much older than the one I saw yesterday; a real old Norman stronghold. Three companies, and all the officers are billeted in a big chateau here. It is a fine place; was the property of an enemy subject; and it has been seized by the French Government. Picked big, luscious, blackberries this evening. The signs say that we will rest here a day or two. We have hustled over 50 miles during the past three days wherefore the hurry I wonder?
Entry.211: Was paid 20 Franc’s yesterday. I am enjoying the spell in this pleasant area. We exercise vigorously in the grounds of this chateau; and carry out some brisk route marches. Received some letters and parcels.
Entry.212: The Vote on the Conscription Referendum was taken yesterday. I don’t think the troops are keen on it. Did not get a vote. A battalion Parade; the colonel warns us that we will see more fighting before we are much older. Have orders to move off at midnight. I am sorry to leave my White Chateau, I doubt if we will ever get another home like it. Had a white frost this morning the first I’ve seen this winter.
Entry.213: Marched about 7 miles to the railway at St.Omer. Entrained at 4 A.M. It seems a nice city, but this is usually our share of these big towns. Tramping through while it is asleep. Passed Calais, Bolounge and Etaples; detrained at Longpre. Crossed a fine stream, the "Somme" I believe and halted at this village; L.Etoile it is called. The name means; "A Star". Besides other things Rum! can be purchased in this exellent place; so the warriors are happy. There is an old roman camp on a hill top near, the ramparts and other defences are still to be seen. It is shaped like a star, perhaps that is how this place gets its name.
Entry.214: Have had very heavy frosts the last couple of days. Church Parade this morning. Spent the afternoon round the town. Saw two lions that a resident of the town has in captivity; splendid beasts both of them. Dined off horse steak, it was good too, but I am ready to eat anything these days. Left this town in the evening; it was too popular, and spent the rest of the day in "Les Moulin Rouge" a hamlet 3 Kilos away. Had a physical argument with some Tommies. Got back home at midnight after a pleasant day.
Entry.215:
Got away early, and after a short march, we were met by a huge convoy of French motor-bus’s.
