They conveyed the whole division about 35 miles. My Battalion was taken to a certain point from whence we marched through much mud; to a camp near Fricourt. Raining heavily. The French motor drivers seem to live on bread and choclate; and are dressed in huge hairy goat skin coats.
Entry.216: Marched on through the rain; along roads conjested with traffic. Dumped our packs along the road and donned light fighting order. Halted on a place we call "Mud Hill"; though the whole landscape is a sea of mud; of the consistency of cream. Absolutely no shelter here, but I have found a possie in an old trench. Am drenched to the skin and covered with mud. Don’t enjoy the prospect of fighting in this weather.
Entry.217: Still hanging on here while it rains with maddening persistency. Have sewed large patches of yellow cloth on our backs and are fitted out for a big stunt. I have never seen so many troops as there are massed here. At night the camp fires on the hills and in the valley look like the lights of a great city. The sight of the transport, and guns pouring along roads knee deep with mud is indescribable. Have excavateded a little cave for myself in the chalk; and only appear at meal times. We are ordered to be ready to move to the line at a moment’s notice. There are big things in the wind for our rations are very liberal, and we get rum every day.
Entry.218: Moved up to the Reserve Trenches in front of Delville Wood. There has been fierce fighting in this wood, even now it is heaped with corpses. The mud here is sickening; I found a "Tommy" bogged in it, and it took four of us half-an-hour to get him out. He was in a shocking state of exhaustion; but game enough. I marvel how this city bred Englishmen stand it. The flashes of our guns illuminate the whole sky, we are very strong in artillery now. The German lines are visible from here; at night his rockets rise continually, Red, Green, White, and a beautiful yellow one we call "Golden Rain". I have a very wet home here, I’m afraid it will fall in on top of me soon.
Entry.219: Rain! Rain! Rain! We got some rum this morning, that is one bright spot in the day. My home collapsed on top of me last night. Spend a wet miserable day. Was attached to Brigade Head Quarters this evening. Went down and reported and set to and made myself a "doss" on a pile of "Stokes" mortar bombs; it is dry; but I guess I will go up if a shell hits this pile tonight. I shall make myself a home tomorrow.
Entry.220:
Spent the day contructing a nice new home. Succeeded in stealing much good material for same and I am very pleased with the result. Also pinched a pair of gum thigh boots; I need them

for the mud is over the knees in places. It is good to be attached to these high places; plenty of rum and rations. I will do duty as Gas Sentry. over the H.Q. dugout.
Entry.221:
This job will do me. Four hours on, and eight off. We get shelled here otherwise an uneventful life. I rescued a packhorse from a bog hole in the road today. It is good to get a chance to do these poor beggars a good turn, they serve us well. There is a battery of howitzers in position near here. It is great to watch them firing at night. No light is seen in the gun pits, except a pencil of light from a electric torch that flashes over the sights, an even voice calls the fire orders from a dugout nearby; "Range! Four, five, eight, O.; Charge! No. 5.

Corrector! 1-5-6-0! Elevation! 3-6-0 degrees Direction! 10 minutes Left!" I stop my ears as a voice cries; All ready! Sir!" Immediately comes the order; "Battery! Salvo! Fire!" There is a blinding flash; a deafening report, that almost drowns the shriek of the projectiles as they fly over to Hunland. I inwardly endorse every shot.
Entry.222:
Went souvenir hunting in the Flers village this morning, inspected a crippled "Tank"; otherwise know as "His Majesty’s Land Ship". It is fine today; the first fine day we have had for a fortnight. Dried my blanket and overcoat in the sun. Our observers are making the best of the fine weather too; I counted 52 aeroplanes and 25 Observation Balloons up this evening Everyone’s spirits have risen

a lot too; my mate is outside this dougout; singing a touching ditty entitled; "Just Before the Battle; Mother" as he scrapes the mud off his clothes with a bayonet.
Entry.223: Our Colonel, O.G. Howell-Price was sniped this morning. There is to be a stunt in the morning. I have been detailed as a special "runner" to bring back messages from the advanced position. Our guns are firing furiously; making one continual roar of sound.
Entry.224:
The Brigade attacked this morning very early. Went forward with some of ‘C’ Company on the right; and after some unpleasantness, gained the objective. The 1st on the left were repulsed, and the 3rd retired from their unsupported position at 

dawn. It was murder to send men over the top in this weather; some were shot down as they stood waist deep in the mire; unable to move. I rejoined the Company. These trying conditions have been telling on the boys. There are some bad cases of trench feet. Word was received, that our Colonel has died of wounds. We will miss him for he was a very gallant gentleman.
Entry.225:
Conditions are very trying here have no tobacco, not the least of my troubles. Two young Huns came in and surrended to me this morning; one was a cool specimen said his mother told him to surrender a good many Huns have given themselves up to us on this sector; they are mostly out of Saxon Regiments;

that have been stiffened with Prussian troops. They say they are sick of the treatment they receive from the overbearing Prussians.
Entry.226: Was releived last night after another, nightmare day. Company Head Quarters drank the rum issue and got dead drunk; so the releif was go-as-you-please. The whole company got lost in this wilderness of mud. It took me hours to stagger out to an English Battery near Longwall. I think I fell a hundred times, but was with some other chaps who helped me up. The English gunners treated us handsomely; gave us rum and food and cigarettes. We all felt better then and laid down in the rain and slept till daylight. Found the Battalion in Trones Wood.
Entry.227: We are in Reserve in Trones Wood. Do a bit of carring fatigue taking engineers stores, etc. to the line. The officer that drank our rum has been sent away for his health. He ought to be hung. They sent old "Digly" away and left that fellow in command.
Entry.229: Brigade releived us, and we moved back to Bermafay Wood. There is a Red Cross stall, with "bacshee" cocoa on tap, near here, it is very popular. Some mail was issued. had letters from home.
Entry.230:
Moved out to bivouac near fricourt. The boys were pretty weak so there was not much order kept; besides the road was crowded with 

traffic. Saw the Prince of Wales today; he looked aggravatingly clean; also the famous, Guards Division; they are a fine, big, lot of fellows. Was paid 40 Fs.
Entry.231: Struck camp yesterday and marched 9 miles or so, crossed the River Ancre and halted at this village Buire-Sur-Corbie. A very cold day. We have been issued with large sheepskin gloves they are exellent; in this frosty weather. This village is no class. Fooled round all day scraping the mud off ourselves and off our equipment.
Entry.232:
Left Buire, and got aboard motor lorries. They conveyed us through Amiens to the town of Flesselles, distance about 30 kilos I have a good possie on a heap of straw where I hope to have a real good sleep.

There was some snow last night. I thought it was frost at first. Paraded early to hear that the fiat has gone forth; saying that we are very lax, and need to be straightened up; so the next week or so will be spent, doing infantry training, and "physical jerks", to make us fit to go "once more to the breach";. A nice district this; I am looking forward to a pleasant holiday.
Entry.233:
A week’s training in fair weather has brought back our old "snap". I guess we will not be long now. Wangled a leave pass to Amiens yesterday, got back this morning. After a dinkum good time; for it is a splendid big city, and has

 

all the comforts of civilisation. A big shipment of Christmas parcels have arrived, so we eat much good, rich, food. Another holiday for me today; but we have orders to move at 4 A.M. tomorrow. So, all things bright and lovely. Finish!
Entry.234: Got away at 7 A.M. The motor transport carried us to Dermacourt, from there ‘D’ Company, marched to a camp near Mametz. There is an air of mystery about this move I don’t know what is the meaning of it.
Entry.235:
Moved about a mile to Fricourt where we are camped in huts. I am told, that we are here to demolish German dugouts and salvage the timber; construct railways, roads, and

other light labour, for eight hours each day. Working today clearing down a luxurious German dugout, it has several rooms, wall paper on the walls, electric light, and bell system. And proof against anything but british troops with bomb and bayonet. They say it was a hospital; for the body of a female nurse was found in one of its galleries. Not the first time I have seen traces of women in German dugouts. The Hun defences here were immensely strong; I will enjoy demolishing them. It is better than the firing line. Was paid 20.Frs
Entry.236:
Continued the salvage work yesterday. I went with a party this morning, to work on the construction of a new camp called "Sydney"

It is going to be "some" camp, winter quarters for the troops. All the huts are of the type known as "Bow Huts". They are all delivered in sections and have only to be bolted together. They measure about 25 feet by 14; and hold up to 40 men.
Entry.237:
Employed these days on the railway at Willow Siding. Stacking sleepers, rails, and other junk. Wet foggy weather continues. Located Arch McIlveens unit about 200 yards from here. This is a good job; too good to last I’m afraid; although; it is very cold, and we sit around fires to keep ourselves warm, when there is nothing doing. This morning I heard a "Tommie" remark; "Where there is smoke there is Australians, this weather;".

Decemmber
Entry.238:
1916.

Worked down at Sydney Camp today. Fitted some more "bow Huts" together. Last night Palmer, Agnew, and I went forageing to Becourdel, a ruined hamlet near here; found a B.E.F. canteen. Found the price of a case of whisky amongst us. Prepared an order; with the necessary signature of an officer; and managed to get a case of "White Horse". With various other provender we boys of 16 Platoon had a "Barbecue" last night I brought home a case of MacKenacies Meat & Vegetable rations this evening there was a tin for each of the chaps. Where did I get it? – Hush! It will keep the wolf from the door for a while. Hard work in this cold weather puts an edge on my appetite that would split a hair.
Entry.239: Did a half days work today, then went for a bath; at the new bath house in the valley. I had not bathed for quite a while; and thought it would kill me, it was delicious however. Working on the demolishing gang. I am all admiration for the industry of the Bosche. His labour has made the country round here like a gigantic rabbit warren. I don’t wonder that he thought this position impregnable. Some of the communication tunnels are hundreds of yards long.
Entry.240: Had a novel expierence yesterday; a fine clear day. Hamilton "V.C." joined up again today, with other details and reinforcements. Have received much Christmas mail. Nothing to do today except keep warm.
Entry.241: Spent the day loafing at Willow Siding. There is a big gun on the railway not far away. When it fires one feels the ground tremble about five seconds before the report is heard. It is a 9.2, and has a range of about 15 miles.
Entry.242: During the last three days, we constructed a large drain. It is about three miles long. Some drain. There is rain every day. I collected several books from vacant dugouts the first I have seen for years.
Entry.243:
The company has been re-organised and I have been selected as a "wire cutter"; a specialist of the first wave. I view these preparations with disfavour. Was

working on the old German line at Fricourt. Cold sleet and snow; there was only one fire; I could not get near it, till I removed the explosive from a German bomb and threw it into the fire; I had it to myself then, because the boys fled. A French civilian visited Fricourt under escort and recovered his cash box from the foundations of a house.
Entry.244:
Fell for some heavy tumbling lately. Shovelling macdam into motor lorries. They say that 800 tons of macdam a day is used in the construction and repair of roads in this sector. Every yard of them has to be constructed over, shell torn grounds, that would bog a duck. It is almost impossible to recognise this place now as the same area

we passed over a month ago. It is a network of roads and railways. Comfortable camps have rose like mushrooms; generally, the work done is incredable. "Gentle Annie"; the gun on the railway found a mark this evening and fired several shots.
Entry.245:
Have shovelled enormous quantities of gravel lately. I really beleive that the

regulation army shovel is winning the war. Was paid 20 Fr this evening, a very popular event. Will seek diversion; there is a train going out from Willow Siding presently; and I will be aboard and ride out to Dermacourt.
Entry.246:
Coming home from Dermacourt with one of the fellows last night

a Military Policeman stopped us on the road and wanted us to show reason why he should not arrest us as deserters! The devotion to duty these gallant fellows show, is touching. He did not "pinch" us however; although my mate was sarcastic, and pointed out to him; that as a non-combatant, he should 

get himself paraded when he wanted to speak to fighting men. Spent the Day giving banjo selections on the gravel dump.
Entry.247: "Froggie" drivers brought in another trainload of macdam. We sent it on, to pave the way to Berlin. A fall of snow this afternoon after a hard frost this morning. The snow covered up the hideous water soaked landscape and made it look clean and nice.
Entry.248: My last day on fatigue; threw my last shovelful of gravel into the lorries marked "Road Repairs"; and marched with the Company this afternoon to "Melbourne" camp where we rejoined the Battalion. The usual preparations; issue of Bombs, Ammunition, etc; before proceeding to the trenches. Have received a parcel of goodies from home; am saving them for the "line"
Entry.249: Moved through a snow storm, via Montuban, to Bernafay Wood. Camped in little tarpaulin shelters for the night. A transformation has come over this area too. It is some comfort to know we are firmly consolidated here.
Entry.250: Went into support. A good duckboard track all the way now. We have shelter in large tunnels excavated in the chalk. We are crowded into a sitting position all the time but it is dry, thank Heaven! There is no ventilation and the shortage of fresh air is very noticeable; no wonder, with all the steaming humanity that is packed into the place. Did fatigue half the night. The downpour of rain is increasing.
Entry.251:
Stayed in the tunnel all day. Had our feet inspected several times; as trench feet is rampant amonst us. We get whale oil to rub on them, but I prefer dry massage. Received a new pair of boots for my broken pair. Have rubbed my

issue of whale oil into them; it make keep the icy slush out when I go out tonight. I am with a party that carries hot rations to the firing line twice every night. The food is carried in large steel thermo. containers, that we strap on our backs. We go straight across the open as there are no trenches, they are either full of water or have fallen in. The foul air here is putting my candle out.
Entry.252:
Did two trips with the food "containers" last night. Fritz spotted us on the last trip and signaled his artillery with two green lights, got "strafed" very briskly for a while. The ground is covered with a frozen crust now. We break through it in places and sink to our knees

in the slush beneath. Carring loads through this is very tiresome. Will go up and occupy the front line on the Guedecourt sector tonight; orders were gravely read, that there is to be no fraternisation with the enemy on Christmas Day. I suppose the "heads" think we will want to kiss Fritz under the mistletoe or something.
Entry.253:
Last night was the worst I ever "put in" in my life. Had some causualties in the company during the releif. Volunteered as a stretcher bearer. Six of us had to carry a wounded man on a stretcher, through the mud, waist deep in places. Got some rum when I returned to the dugout, but our Rations have been lost so there was nothing to eat except a piece of dry bread and "Somme" mud. This, and the memories 

of other Christmas dinners I had eaten; was my Christmas dinner this year. I am in a large German dugout where we sleep during the day time. No movement is allowed during the day for the position is much exposed
Entry.254: Received a small piece of Christmas pudding last night before midnight so yesterday was Christmas Day. The weather broke and it was fine and clear today. Was on "day post" and witnessed a fight between aeroplanes. One, burst into flames while flying at a great height and was destroyed. The town of Bapaume is plainly visible; behind the German line, the Hun defences before it seem very strong. This position is called "Fritz’s Folly"; why, I cannot imagine. The hun is shelling Geudecourt other wise the front is quiet.
Entry.255: Spent a freezing night in the outposts. There is no shelter in these positions, they are just holes where we stand, deep in half frozen slush for 14 hours each night, watching the enemy lines across the valley. If he was to attack I’m sure I would be too cold to resist him. I am grateful for this dugout that enables us to get a sleep. We are due to be releived from the outposts tonight.
Entry.256:
Was releived from the outpost at 10 P.M. last Night. Came back to support in the tunnel. Went over to Flers at 1.30 A.M. and got the food containers; had to take them to the firing line. The weather is very cold. There is a Comforts Fund stall here issuing hot cocoa to the fellows. it is a splendid idea. We received a 

good rum issue after our fatigue this morning, it made some of the fellows very drunk; so weak and exhausted are they. But it is wonderful how this stuff brings back your strength and enables one to sleep. These terrible conditions would kill a horse. I had not dreamed the human frame could stand such hardship. A german aeroplane came over and observed the entrance to this tunnel this morning. His gunners are busy dropping shells on the entrance now; he is making poor practice.
Entry.257:
Out again to the line with rations early this morning. Had a terrible time in the darkness and rain. The strain is telling on me and I am much weaker. Got down in a shell hole to escape the fire of a Bosche Machine gun; and when struggling to stand

up under the weight of the steel "containers" I fell face down in the mud and could not get up. I was afraid I would drown there, miserably; but luckily some chaps came by; and dragged me out of the hole by the legs. Then I saw the two green lights rise out of his line and just had time to scuttle into cover, before the answering barrage arrived. Came back by a new route; because he was due to "strafe" the track at 4.30 A.M. so it was best to avoid it. This is one of "Fritz’s" good points; he is so methodical that one gets to know his routine, and is able to dodge a good deal of his "hate" by knowing just when a certain point is due to be shelled. Our 24 hours "rest" ? is up this evening, and we have to go back to the outposts at "Fritz’s Folly"; The weather is freezing cold.
Entry.258:
Reoccupied the outposts last night I am posted on No.7. this time it is worse than the other one. We stand in the mud and water, from 5 P.M. in the evening until 6.30 A.M. the following morning. Dreadful cramp grips the muscles and sinews and the fellows cry with the agony of it. I became so stiff last night that, when I overbalanced, I fell like a log, face downwards into the mire and could not move for a while. No sleep today; the Hun has been trying to destroy these dugouts; he is using 11 inch, armour piercing shell. He has destroyed the H.Q. dugout thirty yards away, but has failed to get a direct hit onto this one as yet. Although this dugout is 30 feet deep, one of these shells will crush it like an egg shell. He has put some very

close, the concussion from them was terrific. There is an officer buried under the H.Q. dugout, some of the chaps are working trying to get him out.
Entry.259:
Duty in the outpost last night was a terrible ordeal. There was pitiless rain and the water rose and rose; it was bitterly cold too. One poor fellow collapsed, and although we tried to restitute him, he died. I survived the ordeal somehow and got back to the dugout at daylight. We were releived from the outpost at 10 P.M. I helped my mate, who was very sick; to Company Headquarters; where I managed to get a double issue of rum. Because of my exhausted condition it made me very drunk, but it gave me the strength of a madman, and enabled me to make 

my way out over two miles of shell torn, water soaked, ground to our Reserve position in Gap Trench, where I crawled into a shelter and slept. Another night in that infernal outpost would have killed me; as it is I am utterly worn out.
